12.38.text:
All right, so the
idea is to believe

16.18.text:
Of course, this requires a
childlike state of wonder.

18.97.text:
As Alan Harrington wrote
in The Immortalist,

20.80.text:
we must all remain
uncompromising child voyagers--

23.97.text:
retain a child's eye
view of what might be.

27.48.text:
What happens with
adults is that we

29.08.text:
become jaded-- the
been theres and done

34.88.text:
It's a form of dispensing
with the here and now

39.47.text:
It's a sort of impatience
with lived life

43.66.text:
We need to re-engage
with the senses.

45.97.text:
We need awaken the
mind's attention

48.85.text:
from the lethargy of custom
and the film of familiarity,

53.17.text:
and redirecting it instead
to the wonders of existence.

58.12.text:
Absolute unmixed attention
is a form of prayer.

66.13.text: This is the eye of the child.

68.58.text: This is the mind of the child.

74.89.text:
And then it just gets
pummeled out of us.

77.31.text:
It gets stripped
away by banality.

80.47.text:
What is banality and boredom, if
not defences the educated mind,

85.53.text:
employs against experience
so that it's not continually

89.03.text:
exhaustingly astonished,
as Michael Pollan wrote

93.17.text:
And it's true, it would be
astonishing to be open to it

100.07.text:
But we must, nonetheless,
strive to reenter these spaces,

104.87.text:
because these are the
only spaces that have ever

106.87.text:
led to visions that have
transformed the world.
